The tone was subdued.
The tone was dignified.
The tone was flat - a lot of the debate.
It was about 90 minutes long - about 85 to 90 minutes long.

And all of the candidates, while several of them tried to break out of it, all of them found themselves constrained by a format and by a very strict moderator who would not really allow them to talk about what they wanted to talk about or talk as long as they wanted.
And it made them all a little less animated than we are expecting them to be.
Iowa is a state that has some very specific wants and needs of the populace.
Tell us about that.

That was one of the themes of the debate - was that Iowans are a little different, that they might care about Iraq and immigration as the moderator Carolyn Washburn, editor of the Des Moines Register, told us at the beginning.
But they care more about other things.
So the debate was not to be about Iraq and immigration, which, of course, the candidates were expecting to talk about.
It was going to be about other things.
It was going to about debt.
It was going to be about government spending.
It was going to be about issues that Republicans in Iowa, according, at least, to the Des Moines Register, cared more about than some of these other national and international questions.
So that was where they went.

And they talked a lot about how much taxation of these candidates felt they could eliminate, how many government jobs these candidates had eliminated whenever they had had an opportunity to do so, how teachers unions were at fault for what was wrong with the schools, and things of that nature.
Now, when you think about last night, but also more broadly, is anyone really sealing the deal on the Republican side?

Baltimore's residents were on edge last night.
Early in the evening, a group of cars drove up to a line of police protecting the remains of a charred CVS.
They honked horns, revved engines and eventually drove away.
But one man, who didn't give his name, felt trapped by those police.
Look how they got us blocked off.
This is our neighborhood.
Would you go downtown in Baltimore?
You go to the Inner Harbor, and you see they got the National Guard down there protecting white Baltimore.
Another man, named Lasean Robinson, was carrying a yellow sign that read, justice for Freddie Gray.
This is rebellion.
This is years of frustration.
This community has been ignored and would've continued to be ignored had not this happened.
And it probably will, after this, you know, blows over, become ignored again.
